Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 12:07PM Alex517 wrote: Thanks to everyone who responded.  My "sis" talks to her surgeon tomorrow.  I met him a few months back and he seems reasonable and honest, so I hope he shares with her whatever facts are known.  I was reading in the 4th edition of Susan Love's Breast Book (2005) that she felt when different prognosticators are discovered and used in the future, the removal of lymph nodes will not be necessary.  This can't happen soon enough.  And it also sounds like lymphadenectomy doesn't really make a significant difference in the rate of recurrence of axillary tumors.  I'm not sure what she'll decide but I'm hoping she has peace about it.  Thanks again!

Posts.Content: Alex517 wrote: My sister in law just had a bilateral and tram flap procedure a week ago.  Her plastic surgeon shared with her the pathology report today that stated, although her  sentinel node was negative, there were cancer cells found in 3 of the additional 4 nodes removed (apparently this occurs 5% of the time, according to the doc).  I had breast cancer diagnosed last year, and had 2/5 positive nodes and requested no additional nodes be taken as I wanted to avoid the risk of negative sequelae of a full axillary dissection.  Her docs want her to have the full axillary dissection as it is standard of care.  My questions:  Isn't the removal of nodes done to help stage the disease rather than done as a therapeutic procedure ( the removal of disease)?  How significant a change would there be in chemotherapy if she were to be staged at IIIA instead of IIB?  I don't think there is any difference from what I've researched, and the stats regarding recurrence or survival rates at the different stages seems to me to only be disheartening psychologically rather than helpful in any treatment way.  Thank you! Dx 6/13/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 2/5 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 12:47PM Alex517 wrote: She is in her third week of chemo (2nd dense dose administered this past Monday) and handling chemo much better this round.  She is doing A/C, which I did also, but she is healing from the tram and double mastectomies and the subsequent FAD.  Poor dear.  She hasn't had much time to process all of this and I'll be 9 months out of treatment when I have the tram flaps done.  It's been really hard for her physically aside from the emotional and psychological.  She didn't have any more positive nodes with the additional 20 they removed. Oh well....

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 12:54PM Alex517 wrote: Oh, and I wanted to share with you, a few months after my radiation I started to have range of motion issues.  With the added third field of radiation my upper chest and shoulder have suffered from fibrotic tissue encapsulating a few of the nerves in the area. I just decided to begin physical therapy this month as the pain and stiffness was interfering with my job (dentist). And things are improving. No matter what I don't regret not having the full axillary dissection and I think they would have chosen to zap the supraclavicular nodes anyway.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 03:27PM Alex517 wrote: My sis had her lymphadenectomy this afternoon following a tumor board discussion last week.  She will be three weeks from her tram flap tomorrow.  This will delay her chemo which was scheduled to start in a week, for 3-4 weeks.  She is having A/C and T because of the positive lymph nodes.  We didn't find out why the tumor board decided it was in her best interest, but perhaps because it is standard of care, regardless of her livelihood and the need for her right arm to be working properly as a hair stylist, this is what they decided. Here's hoping she has no lasting side effects from this additional surgery!

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 06:28PM Alex517 wrote: Dear Pinky Lee, This is all very tough and having low days doesn't mean anything in regard to outcome, and there will be some days you will have your down moments.  There will also be days in the future that optimism gets a foothold....look forward to them!  My sister and I who are both BRCA 2+ went to a FORCE meeting where some of the ladies share the outcomes of their surgeries.  We saw two ladies who had the Lat Flaps done and their results were absolutely gorgeous!  One of the gals had had a failed expander situation at first, but found a great PS who specializes in the Lats.  The esthetics were tremendous!  "Foobs" perhaps, but they looked and felt very real.  If you have chemo ahead of you after surgery, do take the ativan.  It will help you get a good night's sleep and lift your spirits.  The road ahead is indeed arduous, but you will look beautiful and you will regain your health!  :)
